You can definitely incorporate these exercises into your existing strength training routine. Since you've already been doing squats and lunges, you can replace some of those exercises with the new ones I suggested. Here's a suggestion:

**Replace 1-2 exercises per session:**

* If you're currently doing 3-4 exercises per strength training session, replace 1-2 exercises with the new ones I suggested. For example, if you're doing squats, lunges, deadlifts, and leg press, you could replace squats and lunges with glute bridges and step-downs.
* Start with replacing one exercise per session and see how your body adapts. If you feel like you need more variety, you can replace another exercise in the next session.

**Add 1-2 exercises per session:**

* If you have time and energy, you can add 1-2 new exercises to your existing routine. This will give you more variety and help target your core, glutes, and legs from different angles. For example, you could add Russian twists and calf raises on a step to your existing routine.

**Focus on 2-3 exercises per muscle group:**

* Aim to do 2-3 exercises per muscle group (core, glutes, legs) per session. This will help you target each muscle group effectively without overdoing it.
* Make sure to balance your routine by doing exercises that target different muscle groups. For example, if you're doing glute bridges, you might not need to do step-downs in the same session.

**Listen to your body:**

* Pay attention to your body and adjust your routine as needed. If you feel like you're doing too much or not enough, adjust the exercises, sets, reps, or weight accordingly.
* Remember to warm up properly before strength training and cool down afterwards to prevent injuries.

By incorporating these exercises into your existing routine, you'll be able to target your core, glutes, and legs from different angles, which can help improve your running efficiency and endurance.
